docs.snippet: Richard C. Holbrooke's answer to the question of whether a Democratic administration would have prosecuted the war as well as the Bush administration has is Clintonian in its disingenuousness (The Way We Live Now, March 24). Of course the military...
docs.lead_paragraph: Richard C. Holbrooke's answer to the question of whether a Democratic administration would have prosecuted the war as well as the Bush administration has is Clintonian in its disingenuousness (The Way We Live Now, March 24). Of course the military leadership is essentially the same. But the military acts at the order of the commander in chief, not on its own. Holbrooke's assertion that any president would have responded as Bush did is not borne out by the facts. The previous Democratic administration, in which Holbrooke served, failed on more than one occasion to respond to terrorist acts against the United States in New York, Yemen, Nigeria, Somalia, etc. When it did use the military, it was ineffective to say the least. E. Patrick Mosman Pleasantville N.Y.
docs.abstract: E Patrick Mosman letter comments on Mar 24 interview with Richard C Holbrooke

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The argument that the country has a moral and financial obligation to the descendants of slaves is deeply flawed. Charles J. Ogletree Jr. (Op-Ed, March 31) himself recognizes it when he writes that the cases he cites as precedent...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The argument that the country has a moral and financial obligation to the descendants of slaves is deeply flawed. Charles J. Ogletree Jr. (Op-Ed, March 31) himself recognizes it when he writes that the cases he cites as precedents involved individual litigants who are ''both alive and easily identified.''
docs.abstract: Stanley E Brush letter says Charles J Ogletree Jr's arguments for slavery reparations are deeply flawed (S)

docs.snippet: GARDNER-John W. John Gardner's mark on Carnegie Corporation of New York, where he served as president from 1955 to 1965, is indelible. He arrived at the foundation after his service in WWII, imbued with the optimistic American spirit that this cou...
docs.lead_paragraph: GARDNER-John W. John Gardner's mark on Carnegie Corporation of New York, where he served as president from 1955 to 1965, is indelible. He arrived at the foundation after his service in WWII, imbued with the optimistic American spirit that this country's values could help transform a world wracked by war. He believed in the power of ideas and in the determination of man to change. Gardner shared our founder Andrew Carnegie's unwavering passion for the mission he established for our institution, that ``the advancement and the fusion of knowledge and understanding'' could ``do real and permanent good'' in the world. Like Carnegie, Gardner believed the greatest evil of all is ignorance. The board of trustees of the Corporation, its staff, both present and past, are thankful for John Gardner's service, leadership and legacy. Vartan Gregorian, President, Carnegie Corporation of New York

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  Gardner, John W.

docs.snippet: President Bush's proposed $2.1 trillion budget embraces the word ''security'' at every turn. It provides more spending for military security and domestic security and more tax cuts for ''economic security.'' But the budget undermines the security ...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's proposed $2.1 trillion budget embraces the word ''security'' at every turn. It provides more spending for military security and domestic security and more tax cuts for ''economic security.'' But the budget undermines the security of the nation's social safety net and the government's ability to carry out some of its basic responsibilities over the next two decades. It jeopardizes the future of Social Security and Medicare, whose trust funds would be siphoned away to underwrite outmoded military projects and tax reductions favoring the rich. The budget embodies a divisive agenda for which Mr. Bush has no mandate, in spite of his popularity. For weeks the administration has cleverly leaked news about a handful of domestic programs like family nutrition, health research and food stamps that were targeted for spending increases. But the budget the administration presented yesterday revealed that everything outside these few programs was up for assault. According to Mitchell Daniels, the budget director, the administration is targeting only inefficient programs. The cuts, he insists, are not aimed at hobbling job training, environmental programs or labor safety -- although those are some of the areas that will suffer. The administration, he says, is simply trying to do away with bad management. Mr. Daniels has created a virtual axis of inefficiency, and declared war on it.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Pres Bush's proposed $2.1 trillion budget undermines nation's social safety net and government's ability to carry out some of its basic responsibilities; says budget is road map toward different kind of American society, in which government no longer taxes rich to aid poor and in fact does very little to protect nation from foreign enemies; says if budget is adopted as proposed, increasing cost of tax cuts over next decade will drain treasury while rapidly rising price tag of unnecessary military projects will make up larger and larger piece of what is left; charges that Bush is using anti-terrorism campaign to disguise ideological agenda that has nothing to do with domestic defense or battling terrorism abroad

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Nicholas D. Kristof's mathematical gymnastics (''A Merciful War,'' column, Feb. 1) are initially dazzling but ultimately unpersuasive. While the human cost of the American bombing of Afghanistan is now entirely clear, the benefit...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's mathematical gymnastics (''A Merciful War,'' column, Feb. 1) are initially dazzling but ultimately unpersuasive. While the human cost of the American bombing of Afghanistan is now entirely clear, the benefits that he projects are speculative and will accrue, if ever, many years from now. As a result, it's not at all obvious that the bombing makes sense even under the utilitarian calculus that Mr. Kristof finds appealing. In any event, if health care for Afghans had really been our concern, wouldn't the millions of dollars spent on bombs have been better spent on hospitals and health education?
docs.abstract: Jameel Jaffer letter disputes Nicholas Kristof's February 1 Op-Ed article on US military campaign in Afghanistan

headline.main: In Afghanistan, For Better or Worse

docs.snippet: CURRY-Charles MacNeil, Jr., MD. Died March 30, 2002 at Memorial Hermann Hospital, University of Texas from complications following heart surgery. He was 58. A graduate of Holy Cross College, Univ. of St. Louis Medical School, and Univ. of Pennsylv...
docs.lead_paragraph: CURRY-Charles MacNeil, Jr., MD. Died March 30, 2002 at Memorial Hermann Hospital, University of Texas from complications following heart surgery. He was 58. A graduate of Holy Cross College, Univ. of St. Louis Medical School, and Univ. of Pennsylvania Neurosurgery Program. Called to active duty during Vietnam War from a residency at Neurologic Institute at Columbia, he served for two years at St. Alban's Naval Hospital. He was a pioneer in the development of emergency room medicine in hospitals throughout the metro area. Survived by three sons, MacNeil, Fraser and Emerson. He was a member of The Brook, Westminster Kennel Club, ASPCA and past-Vice President of The Leash. A memorial service will be held at St. John's on the Mountain at Bernardsville, NJ, Thursday, April 18th at 11AM.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRY, CHARLES MACNEIL, JR., MD.

docs.snippet: Nassau County's emergency command center for dealing with disasters is hidden amid a maze of hallways and tunnels some 25 feet beneath Police Headquarters here. But these days it is the center itself that looks as if it had been hit by a disaster....
docs.lead_paragraph: Nassau County's emergency command center for dealing with disasters is hidden amid a maze of hallways and tunnels some 25 feet beneath Police Headquarters here. But these days it is the center itself that looks as if it had been hit by a disaster. A dozen missing tiles give the ceiling a jumbled, checkerboard look. Tangles of wires and cables dangle randomly here and there. Hanging from one set of wires is a fire-alarm bell.
docs.abstract: Nassau County's emergency command center for dealing with disaster appears to have been poorly and haphazardly maintained; center is hidden amid maze of hallways and tunnels some 25 feet beneath Police Headquarters in Garden City; County Exec Thomas R Suozzi tours center, to dramatize his insistence that county had better prepare itself for terrorist attacks and other disasters; photos (M)

headline.main: Nassau's Disaster Command Post Looks a Lot Like a Disaster Site Itself
